summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office to Judge Alison J. Nathan providing an update on Ghislaine Maxwell's conditions of confinement at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC). It details her access to discovery, attorney communication, daily routine, and addresses complaints raised by the defense regarding searches, food, water, and cell conditions.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell was granted extensive access to review discovery: 13 hours per day, 7 days a week, with exclusive use of two computers in a day room.
Maxwell had 25 hours per week of video-teleconference calls with her attorneys, with provisions to make up for any delays, and the option for in-person visits seven days a week.
The MDC investigated and rejected a defense complaint about an inappropriate pat-down search, finding it was recorded and conducted appropriately.
MDC staff directed Maxwell to clean her cell after it became very dirty and smelly, noting she frequently did not flush her toilet; this was stated not to be retaliation.
Maxwell's legal mail is processed like all other inmates', which can take multiple days, but she has daily email and regular VTC communication with counsel.
